questions.text: The $\mathbf{Toulmin \, Model \, of \, Argumentation}$ specifies a $\mathbf{Warrant}$ as the $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Data or evidence
options.c: Unstated assumption or principle that connects the data to the claim

questions.text: What is the $\mathbf{rhetorical \, effect}$ of using a $\mathbf{periodic \, sentence}$ (main clause at the end)?

options.a: To create a sense of simplicity and speed
options.b: To build tension and suspense before revealing the main idea
options.c: To distract the reader with complexity

questions.text: In persuasive writing, $\mathbf{Logos}$ refers to the appeal to $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Credibility

questions.text: An $\mathbf{Enthymeme}$ is a form of syllogism (a deductive argument) in which $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: One premise is left unstated or implied (relies on audience assumption)

questions.text: Which $\mathbf{stylistic \, choice}$ involves the deliberate omission of conjunctions ($	ext{and, \, or, \, but}$) between parts of a sentence ($\text{e.g., \, 'I \, came, \, I \, saw, \, I \, conquered'}$)?

options.b: Anaphora

questions.text: The $\mathbf{Hedge \, (or \, qualifier)}$ in an academic statement serves to $\mathbf{...}$?

options.a: Make the statement sound more certain
options.b: Lessen the certainty, acknowledging limitations or exceptions (e.g., $\text{It \, may, \, it \, seems}$)

questions.text: In a $\mathbf{Technical \, Report}$, the $\mathbf{Abstract}$ should concisely summarize the $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Full content of the report (purpose, methods, results, conclusion)

questions.text: $\mathbf{Document \, Design \, principles}$ (e.g., use of white space, headings, font) are crucial because they directly impact the $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Content's objectivity
options.c: Reader's comprehension and usability of the text

questions.text: The concept of $\mathbf{coherence \, and \, cohesion}$ in advanced writing primarily focuses on $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: The logical and grammatical connectivity between sentences and paragraphs

questions.text: Which rhetorical term refers to a figure of speech in which a part is made to represent the whole or vice versa (e.g., $\text{The \, crown}$ for the monarchy)?

options.b: Synecdoche

questions.text: A sentence that begins with an introductory phrase or dependent clause and saves the main idea for the end is a $\mathbf{...}$ sentence.

options.b: Simple

questions.text: When writing $\mathbf{Standard \, Operating \, Procedures \, (SOPs)}$, the writing style should be $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Persuasive and emotional

questions.text: The phrase $\mathbf{The \, fact \, that}$ often signals $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: A noun clause that is unnecessarily wordy (or a nominalization)

questions.text: The concept of $\mathbf{Tone}$ in professional writing must be carefully managed to align with the $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Specific audience and purpose of the document

questions.text: In a $\mathbf{Proposal \, Report}$, the $\mathbf{budget \, and \, timeline}$ are typically presented as $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: Constraints and resources needed for the proposed solution

questions.text: Which $\mathbf{logical \, fallacy}$ attempts to divert an argument's attention by introducing an irrelevant topic?

options.b: Red Herring

questions.text: The $\mathbf{rhetorical \, concept \, of \, Kairos}$ refers to $\mathbf{...}$?

options.b: The timeliness and appropriateness of an argument or appeal

questions.text: When revising for $\mathbf{voice}$, shifting from $\mathbf{passive}$ to $\mathbf{active}$ voice means ensuring the $\mathbf{...}$ performs the action.

options.b: Adverb

questions.text: A $\mathbf{Discursive \, Essay}$ is one that explores a topic or argument in a $\mathbf{...}$ way.

options.b: Digressive and rambling

questions.text: What is the primary function of $\mathbf{transitional \, paragraphs}$ in a very long report or essay?

options.b: To act as a bridge between major sections, summarizing the preceding part and introducing the next
